key_points: Derek Chauvin found guilty of all charges for killing George Floyd; verdict seen as accountability, not justice by Obama and Biden.
The article critiques the belief that police reforms can solve racial bias, arguing that policing is fundamentally a system of racial and economic control.
It argues that even without racial bias, policing won't solve the problems of inequality and exploitation.
The article highlights the low rate of police convictions despite numerous killings by police, questioning the effectiveness of convictions in preventing future deaths.
Celebration of Chauvin's conviction as justice is challenged; police's broad leeway to use force under the law is criticized.
The same day of the Chauvin verdict, a white cop in Columbus, Ohio, shot and killed 15-year-old Black girl Ma'Khia Bryant.
Recent police killings during the Chauvin trial illustrate ongoing issues with police violence and the lack of justice for victims.
The article argues that convictions provide relief only for the living and do not save lives, questioning what accountability and justice truly mean.
Police abolition, not just reform, is advocated as necessary for societal change.
The piece calls for support of social movements and organizations pushing for police abolition and transformational change.
